newsitem.title: USA: U.S. concerned about Ivcher harassment.
newsitem.headline: U.S. concerned about Ivcher harassment.

text.p: The United States expressed concern on Tuesday about what it called Peru's harassment of Israeli-born television station owner Baruch Ivcher and said the case raises fundamental questions of press freedoms.

U.S. State Department spokesman Nicholas Burns said Ivcher is "being harassed and threatened with criminal prosecution for his television station's reporting and commentary about Peruvian government officials and the Peruvian military."
The Peruvian government on Sunday decided to revoke Ivcher's nationality on grounds of bureaucratic "irregularities."

"This is an issue of concern to us ... These actions raise fundamental questions of freedom of the press, and freedom of expression," Burns told reporters, noting that "the need to respect freedom of expression and of the press is an essential element of democracy and ... American foreign policy."
He added, however, that "if there are any credible criminal or civil charges to be brought against Mr. Ivcher, we expect they will be resolved in fair and open and quick court proceedings."

"We're saying that nothing should be done in a back room. If the Peruvian government believes that he's violated Peruvian law, they ought to say so ... But they (government officials) seem to be operating differently."
The threat to revoke Ivcher's citizenship has sparked a wave of media and public outrage and become a rallying point for Peru's increasingly buoyant opposition.
